ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Sayd Randle
Sarah (Sayd) Randle
Sayde
Sayd Randle was a wonderful TA. She was smart, thoughtful and considerate. Her comments both in class and on assignments were useful. She did a great job!
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sarah was helpful and available.
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sayd Randle.
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sarah is responsive and well organized.
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sayd Randle

Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  The professor and TF urged students to start working on the final papers early. I tried to begin early by submitting my proposal very early in the semester. It took Sayd and Professor Dove several weeks to get back to me on the proposal, at which time they denied it and requested I amend it. I resubmitted and again they took an unreasonable amount of time to reply, making it impossible for me to begin the paper early. In addition, Sayd had some trouble facilitating discussions, often overriding student input and digressing into topics of her own interest.Other than these problems, Sayd was mostly attentive and willing to help students.
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  She was very organized, especially given the size of the class. Very responsive and helpful when approached.
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sayd Randle
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sarah Randle
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sarah Randle (Sayd)
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sarah Randle
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  The teaching fellow was Sarah Randle.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: For Question 13:The class is reading based which is great because the readings relevant and interesting but the Professor has so much experience from his own personal life that I was hoping he would bring that to class apart from the discussions he lead on the readings.The class would be better if he provided situations that he experienced and taught us how we should deal with such situations when facing issues about the society and the environment. Even though this is a foundation course and the aim is to have the students think about what the issues are, in the end you remain confused about what one should do. Maybe that was the point of the course, to provide so many circumstances that you realize all the things that you would not have when dealing with a situation. Nonetheless, even a little bit of building skills to address the issue would have made a huge difference.
Question 11: There was often little opportunity to ask questions during the lecture portion, because Professor Dove would be looking only at his notes or the screen.
There are lots of readings and discussions. A great class overall.

Most of the class material was not relevant to what I am interested in pursuing outside of FES. I should have looked more closely at the course readings prior to enrolling in it, but course options were limited this term given the caps on so many courses and scheduling conflicts with courses I otherwise would have taken. I felt a bit cornered into this course, and found it mostly lacking. Professor Dove's facilitating was illuminating and helpful, but his lectures were mostly dry and simply recited in a monotone that was sometimes difficult to engage with.

This class should be taken by every FES student. Its concepts apply to any type of research or management work- local or international. Although highly theoretical, I find myself thinking of this class a lot as it helps to explain why certain things happen the way they do.

Dove has a very particular style (he speaks slowly and reads all of his lectures from printed notes), but if you can get into that it's a very good course. He also has a subtle and charming sense of humor which breaks things up considerably.
Sarah Randle - I would have liked it if she would have allowed the weekly commentators to lead the discussion a bit more. Despite this she was very insightful.

Course moved way too fast for my ability to really comprehend it all, but it was still a great course. A ton of work, the most of any class of mine this semester, but we also received feedback, so I felt like the learning process worked.
Pacing of the course may be better if we were to focus on a few topics more in depth. There was too much material to be discussed in the discussion time.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The readings were great.

This was my favorite course of the semester, and the most challenging. There wasn't a single reading that I did not find informative and compelling, and Professor Dove's lectures were always insightful. It changed the way I think about 'development problems' and life in general.
Learning about different approaches and frameworks in social science study. Prof. Dove's experience and insights on international development was very helpful to me.
Dr. Dove's lectures.
Exposure to seminal literature in the field
- Some topics were very interesting.- Some papers/books I otherwise would not have read.- Students were mostly engaged and enthusiastic in discussion periods.
The readings were fantastic. The lectures were very good quality as well.
Readings were very relevant and interesting.
Dove's insight during lectures and the readings.
I learn many new things on anthropology which I never had in the past.
Readings, class discussions

The course did a nice job of addressing the readings in lecture but also adding to them such that the lectures were not just a rehashing of the reading. I appreciated the variety of scholarship presented in the readings, as well as the variety of sources utilized for the lectures (video, email exchanges, readings, personal experiences).
The readings were great. Dr. Dove has a lot of insight into anthropological research.

Dr. Dove's lectures were excellent. The readings were almost entirely excellent and fascinating. For me, with some international development experience, this course wasn't so much of an eye-opener as an opportunity to articulate many of the ideas and feelings I'd had. By far the most intellectually stimulating and demanding course I took this semester: this is what I had hoped graduate school would be.

The readings were fantastic. I'm incredibly glad that the assignments were the way they were: concise one-page analyses of three readings. I feel that these assignments pushed my analysis of the readings to a deeper level. They were incredibly hard but completely worthwhile.
The cultural aspects of the environment was a revelation to me. This course also pushes students to think beyond the surface of the subject matter.
I liked how open-ended the term paper assignment was. It really allowed the students to explore a topic that interested them without strict guidelines on the topic.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The Discussion section was too long (a bit more than an hour) and the diversity of the class makes it slightly chaotic because not everyone is on the same page. To address this, I would have preferred having smaller discussion groups that could discuss the readings weekly and then each group could present their ideas at the end of the classAlso, the class size was too big for the classroom so sometimes we had to sit by the window sill and that was uncomfortable

I wish the lecture slides could be made available to students - sometimes Professor Dove would go through them too quickly for note-taking.The classroom was unacceptably overcrowded - people had to sit on the window ledges every time.
1. Would be better if the lecture style is more dynamic;2. Smaller class size might help;3. More instructions for the discussion.

- The nature of the lectures, which I found ineffective for my learning.- The course material should be more relevant to problems and their solutions.- The facilitation of the discussions were hit or miss.
More one on one time with the professor. There were 15 min slots of office hours every week, and I often felt like I did not have time to explain or expand on material seen in class.
Lectures were boring.
I think the course is pretty solid the way it is.

The theory was heavily in the readings and the method was heavily in class, and it would have been nice for a little more of a conceptual linkage to have been made between the two. Additionally, I found the firm division between lecture and seminar off-putting, because it barred engagement with the lecture while forcing it during seminar. I think a more integrated approach, where discussion is interwoven into the lecture and the discussion section draws on presentation would have better helped foster dialogue and allowed me to get more out of the lectures. Sometimes the discussions were like pulling teeth.
I think we would have gotten more out of the class if Dr. Dove and the guest lecturers don't just read their notes and papers instead of lecturing.

Too much reading. I mostly did all of the required readings, and it usually took me at least 1-1.5 days/week, too much time considering all the other class I had to take. If it's not possible to pare down the reading requirements (or if the point is to learn to read this much) it would be great to have more discussion about how to accomplish this: tips, techniques, expectations, etc.The 25-30 page paper was a great way to develop some ideas, but after writing it I realized I don't really know how to write such a thing, and I wasn't able to find the support I wanted at FES. The instructor did give us some great tips and guides for writing the final, but a little more support would have been appreciated. Along these lines, the teacher's office hours would fill up very quickly - maybe making more designated time would appreciated.

The class discussion could be further improved. While splitting the class into two sections did help, I still felt there were too many students within a discussion group. Perhaps further splitting would improve the flow of discussion, which never seemed to move past awkward. Keeping the same groups for longer but switching the TA/professor leading the discussion (instead of mixing up group members multiple times) might also address this issue.

While there were discussion sections after the lecture, it would have been nice to have discussions with the whole group rather than breaking up into two groups. I liked being able to hear everyone's input.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Smaller groups, less discussion time in the class, more outside the class and the professor could add his inputs from his experiences.
Sometimes the discussion sections felt unproductive and awkward, but other times they were great! Maybe more mixing of students would help?
N/A

There was a big difference in the quality of the professor-led discussion session, and the TA-led discussion session. The latter being worse, the TA constantly interrupted, and prevented students from delving into the points they thought important.
Some of the discussions ended up better than others but I think the general layout was effective.
See above.
Discussion groups were very effective.

I didn't think the seminars worked very well. In fact, as the course went on, I found myself really looking forward to Dr. Dove's lectures and the readings, but in a small way dreading the seminars. This is because it felt like there were far too many people in the room, and it became clear we didn't really know how to run/participate in such a discussion. We got sidetracked over and over, the leaders' questions sometimes prematurely cut off discussions, and we often argued over semantics. With as many people as we had in the class, this just didn't work that well. I realize there is an art to participating in a seminar, and maybe more time going over some strategies and ground rules would have been helpful. To be clear, this wasn't just an issue with this class: most of my seminars at FES this semester went the same way. The only ones that seemed to work were those with 4-5 students, as a brief sidetrack was affordable with that few people. I did think Sadie's leadership in the discussions was very beneficial: she is a great facilitator.
The relationship was well thought out and obvious. My comments on question 17 address areas for improvement.
It was effective. The discussion section could be improved with more guidance as to topics to be discussed.

I thought the relationship between lectures and discussion was incredibly effective. It was important to be able to discuss the readings, especially since so many students had not been exposed to this type of class before. At the end of the semester we had discussion with the whole class and I really enjoyed it. I think that for the most part the smaller groups were better, but it might be interesting to have a couple of full-class discussions interspersed in the semester rather than just at the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: The teaching assistant did a great job as the discussion leader and as a tutor/ grader. She always provided good feedback and was willing to help more.

For discussion, it would have been helpful to get approval from the teaching assistant beforehand, as there were often times when she was unhappy with the questions structured by designated discussions leaders - often leaving them empty handed for questions.Otherwise, very helpful and available.
Strengths: intelligent, well versed.Weaknesses: obstinate, confrontational, haughty.

She was very insightful and knowledgeable about the topic and the readings. I would recommend, however, that she not direct the discussion conversations as much and be a little more open to students opinions even if they differ from hers.
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Strengths:1. well organized;2. responsive;3. insightful and give good advice;Weakness:1. not very dynamic;2. sometimes takes over the discussion session;

Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Pro:- Cares about material- Knows material- Interested in engaging in discussionsCon:- Dominates discussions- Redirects discussions away from relevant topics to superfluous or irrelevant topics

Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  She provided helpful feedback on my commentaries and assisted me in organizing my thoughts for the term paper. As a discussion leader, I sometimes felt that in an effort to clarify things, she tried to guide the discussion too much, taking away from the students that were supposed to be leading.

Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sayd had a great grasp of the material and was personable and approachable outside of class. I think she had a little bit of difficulty reading the room during our initial discussion sections. At the beginning of the course, she occasionally stymied discussion section in the way that she asked us to define terms. I think I know what she was going for - wanting us all to be on the same page and understand the concepts we were throwing around - but the way she went about it put people off, I think. Other than that, I think she was a great TA, and I very much enjoyed her lecture.

Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sayd was a great facilitator and really improved the discussions by keeping us on track and holding people accountable for their comments. While a little bit intimidated at first by how interactive she was in the discussions, I quickly realized how beneficial this was and admired her ability to facilitate. It was clear she knew what she was talking about and held people to the same high standard.While her presentation was fascinating, I am not a huge fan of reading from prepared notes. I think it somehow works really well for Dr. Dove, perhaps because of many years of refinement and practice, but for other presenters it gives a feeling a disconnection. Sayd is an interesting, charismatic speaker: she should use these abilities when she gives a presentation. Still, I got over this and immensly enjoyed and learned from her efforts.Sayd also gave great feedback on assignments.All in all, Sadie was an excellent TA and I really appreciate her help.
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sayd did a great job. I'd encourage her to keep up the good work.

Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  I thought that she was very approachable, and a great discussion leader. Sometimes I thought she took control of the discussion section a little too much, but it was usually to lead us to a more productive conversation so ultimately that wasa good thing. Great teaching fellow.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course was supposed to play an extremely important role in my future because I hope to work with communities across tropical countries. The course was effective in making me understand that it is not going to be easy to do so.
It's a class that's outside of my comfort zone. It serves as a great complimentary to my existing concentration.
It adds to my background in natural science.

I am interested in why people think the way they think and act the way they act, and the state of development projects today. This course helps is a good grounding in criticism and scholarship that helps me think about power and cultural production across disciplines.
I have a biological science background so this class was a great intro to the anthropology.

This course wasn't required for my program. Despite that, this course is very valuable, and should be a part of any program. As a result of this course I am much more interested in anthropological perspectives and will probably pursue studies related to social sciences. I had taken many anthropology courses as an undergraduate, none of which did so much to all me to explore and articulate complex ideas about my role in the world.
This directly relates to my overall program and pushed me to think aboutissues through new lens. I really appreciate having taking this course.

I do not wish to study anthropology and my background is much more involved in the natural sciences, but I think this was an important course for me to take. This course taught me to question myself, and I was able to use the term paper assignment to align the course more strongly with my own interests.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I plan to work with communities and it is a foundation course
I'm interested in the intersection between social sciences and environmental studies...and in general, I like to examine the hidden fabric of assumptions and symbols that structure human life.
I wanted to learn about basic methods in sociology.
Because I am interested in the social aspects of environmental work. I had never taken an anthropology course so I thought the foundations course would be an appropriate introduction.
My work relates me with people, hence It will be valuable to understand the human dimension of my field of interest.
To get back into the swing of academia and ground my time here in some serious theory, before focusing more on practical application.
Dr. Dove is a great wealth of knowledge.
I had heard great things about it from 2nd year students. The reading list looked good. Dr. Dove's reputation as an academic is very good.
It is a requirement for other courses I wish to take.

I took this course because I was interested in understanding the social-science side of environmental management. Social science and biophysical sciences are both important to understand when taking on an environmental management role.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Far exceeded them!
Yes.
Yes
Yes although I didn't know what to expect. I had heard positive things about the course and am so happy took the course and stuck with it.
Yes. I get more insight into anthropological inquiry
Yes, I think so.
yes.

Yes. I would have learned even more if we had moved a little slower and had been able to have more productive seminar sessions. Still, this was great introduction to some of the canonical anthropological works.
Exceeded them.

It was different than I had previously anticipated. I find that the knowledge acquired from this course was useful in the development of problem solving. Also, I found that the conceptual knowledge in this course will be useful for many aspects during my career.
It did meet my expectations. I enjoyed all of the readings and I appreciated the opportunity to personalize the course through the term paper.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The group work (commentaries) before the class session were better than discussions inside the classroom.
N/A
I learn to get involve to a discussion

The group work was minimal. Three times in the semester we worked as a group with a few other students to be a discussion leader for the weeks' readings. I really liked the level of group work. I think it was really helpful to have student discussion leaders to help everyone digest the readings. It was also great to be able to meet before the discussion section to come up with questions to ask the class. I think that I got the most out of the readings where I was a discussion leader and met with a group to discuss the readings before class.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The only advice that I can provide is to have fewer expectations from the skills that you will learn from the class. The class has great readings and if you want to discussthat (especially if you have no background in this field), take the class.

Take it! It will be challenging but ultimately worthwhile. This class should be required for anyone who has world-changing aspirations.Also, he's not kidding about starting the paper early. Set aside dedicated time for gathering materials, reading, and note-taking as soon as you have a foggy idea of a topic. I wish I had started that process earlier than November.
1. be on top of the readings;2. start to think and write the final paper early;3. meet and make outlines if you are leading the discussion sessions;
Workload is high, but payoffs are also high.

If you're new to this subject like I was, the beginning of the course can be challenging to follow with the lingo but stick with it, ask questions and by the end of the course it all makes sense. Also, start the term paper early!
Hardworking but it pays in the end.

There are a lot of readings and many are dense. The course is good for your brain, and Dove is a good professor to become acquainted with if you are interested in the social aspects of environmental work, particularly in a foreign context. If you are not interested in development or indigenous peoples, you might want to look elsewhere, but even if you are not interested in working in that field or with agricultural communities, the larger ideas addressed in this course are beneficial in thinking about the unintended impacts decisions and programs can have, across sectors.
start the final paper early.

Start your finalproject early. Write about a limited topic. I chose too broad of a topic and ended up writing a long, somewhat shallow paper, just to cover the bases. In hindsight, I would have much preferred to go deeper and not cover as much.Figure out a way to get the readings done sooner. This might be standard graduate school stuff, but I didn't know how to read and comprehend things fast enough to feel like I had time for these readings and all my other class work.
Deeply read all the readings as if you were writing a one-page analysis of the subject material.
Do not procrastinate. Take notes, it helps in the end. Enjoy the ride.

I think it's a great class. It will teach you to look back and question a lot of things that you have always taken as given. This course teaches you a thought process. Make sure that you give yourself time on the term paper.
